body:
A couple of comments:
- See Philippe's comment above about `sys`
- We should explain how the parameters are encapsulated in the dictionary received as parameter in the main function. We should include an example that shows this. 

When you're done with the above comments, please rebase, squash and ping me.
This seems harmless. Could you please rebase?
Note that orthogonal changes don't need to be rebased by the contributor (it's nice but not necessary as this can be done as part of accepting the pull request).
@domdom82 can you elaborate the instructions to show how to use this more fully - specifically, how does one get the activation logs to run this script.

For now, our solution is similar to the javascript one. We support a series of packages that are (should be) documented. At some point, we may consider a more generalized solution similar to "build packs". @vmtyler

The changes look like they will work. I am a little uncomfortable though with the approach we are taking:

```
$ find nodejsAction/ -type f -exec wc -l {} + | tail -1
925 total
$ find nodejs6Action/ -type f -exec wc -l {} + | tail -1
916 total
$ diff -rw nodejsAction/ nodejs6Action/ | wc -l
104
```

We are copy-pasting a non-trivial set of functionalities (container definition, action wrapper, Whisk "SDK"), with basically no changes except pinning version numbers of the runtime and of the packages. I know we've recently had similar instances of clone-and-own, but never to that extent. Can we refactor this into `core/nodejsCommon` containing almost all the code, and `core/nodejs[6]Action/` using a common base `Dockerfile`? I feel like this is doomed to diverge in unpleasant ways otherwise.

@sjfink @rabbah and others may want to comment and/or suggest better refactoring strategies.

Agreed we should not have multiple copies of all those js files.  It will be a maintenance nightmare.  Your strategy seems fine.  Since docker likes to build things under it, having a separate Dockerfile to build a base is necessary as that Dockerfile will have access to the shared stuff.  And of course, faster builds will be possible if we do it this way.
Seems like some of this will diverge very soon though with issues like #78 and #505.
Clone and own is bad. Extend and override is good.

I have added some more detailed info on how to get logs.

We usually copy out logs from a previous stable Jenkins build and a failed build after we detect errors. The readme describes how to do it manually using wskadmin.

Also rebased and squashed.

looks ok to me. it may be debatable whether `/etc/environment` is too intrusive and `/home/vagrant/.bashrc` is more desirable for this variable. but since this is a VM with only one user this may be overkill.
FWIW We do already modify a local bash profile (for tab completion using the CLI).
@csantanapr LGTM. Is there anyone else that should review this before I merge it?
@bjustin-ibm I think @rabbah should review, since it contains a change in the REST API section.

The activation start and end times in the activation record will allow a user to know: when

> end - start >= action limit

then it was a timeout vs an application error within allowed time. We could adjust the error message accordingly.

I think having an error message/code that indicates a timeout error as opposed to the current error which just indicates that the action did not return valid json, would be a better way of handling the situation

having user do calculation on end - start, it's too low level, I agree proper error message is more usable to users.
Action was terminated because it reach {LIMIT_CONFIGURED_FOR_THIS_ACTION} without completing 
something like that , you know what I mean 😄

+1

on top of that, should there be a corresponding error code, eg a 504?

I think having the 3 are very useful 
1. return code
2. return string
3. stderr message in user logs (user will see it in `wsk activation poll` or UI console)
@houshengbo Can you take a look at comment from @ioana-blue https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/494#issuecomment-223018182 when you have a chance?

@rabbah I created an issue for your comment https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/527#issuecomment-222516972 on $BASEURL.

I think we can merge this PR as it's right now and discuss $BASEURL in the new issue

@rabbah should we change `$BASEURL` to `{APIHOST}` ?

Then explain that `{APIHOST}` is the hostname for openwhisk API endpoint, the same value use to configure API clients like the CLI with `wsk --apihost {hotname}` or `wsk property set apihost {hostname}`

@rabbah I think nodejs it would be better converting from bash to nodejs, using [shelljs](https://www.npmjs.com/package/shelljs) or [cash](https://www.npmjs.com/package/cash) easy and readable code when it comes on execute and handling stdout and stderr.

I favor doing _only_ `2` from the list above. 

We can achieve `3` by projecting the error from the activation during an activation poll. The error field is guaranteed to exist on a bad activation.

We return `BadGateway` already for application/developer errors including actions that timeout and don't produce a response. Consider this nodejs action as an example `function main() { return whisk.async(); }`. This is a developer error and the action will timeout.

> it would be better converting from bash to nodejs, using shelljs or cash

I tend to agree.  In the past, I've made bash scripts truly cross-platform by converting them to Node using the shelljs module. It was very easy and straightforward to accomplish, as well as making my scripts more powerful than when they were written in bash.  

But really... this is probably a discussion for a separate issue/PR 😉
Agree - banishing bash scripts is a separate work item.
I'm OK not writing to stderr 3 above, if we can achieve goal of letting user know what happens when his running `wsk activation poll`
@bjustin-ibm @rabbah We can open an issue to discuss bash scripts to nodejs, Oh Wait I just did 😸  #552

started PPG 558

Can the packages be shared too? I see image magik in the base dockerhost why not all the other packages?

This is borderline nitpicking: the base could have just been the current nodejs action and then the specialization is node4 vs node6. To make the version more explicit (where node4's name is what the system current uses for its kind).

@ioana-blue, and @csantanapr, it is not necessary to add the "import sys".
However, for the explaination how the parameters are encapsulated in the dictionary, I do not think there is too much about it. The beauty of Python is that we do not define the type for any parameters. We can simply name it and use it as the type we like. There can be no key, one key, multiple keys for a dict. We just take it by dict.get('key') or dict['key'] without any declaration. I can add this sort of explanation into the documents, but I do not expect there is more about the parameter encapsulation.
thanks for starting the PPG Perry
This has bugged me for a while too. I'll take a stab at it.
I think the level of parameter related exposition here matches the other language runtimes. I'm inclined to keep it that simple.

ant is just a shell for gradle right now - most of the components are built with gradle already with the exception of this and the CLI (there might be one more). If you look at the ant targets for the core components, they call gradle. Here is just one example: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/build.xml#L36

@psuter - I added a test for testing default function parameters, which is new to node 6.  I threw in the `let` you mentioned as well which not new to node 6, but isn't supported in the existing node we have (0.12.14).  My idea to throw in the Promises to test node 6 was to no avail since those are even supported in our existing node.  Found this nice link for viewing node features by version: http://node.green/

@jasonpet if we kept nodejsAction as is including its docker file, could the nodejs6 action Dockerfile simply upgrade the node version using whisk/nodejsaction as the image base?

the thinking is that we have only one list of packages to maintain instead of two (when we diverge, we'll diverge and make the lists explicit).

@rabbah - I haven't really been able to follow your last few comments regarding the docker file split.  The npm packages are different then the docker packages.  image magik is not an npm package.  The npm packages have different versions based on the node version and even different names in some cases.  Jade was renamed to Pug.

I'm thinking if there is a way to reduce the duplication between the two dockerfiles: primarily so we aren't maintaining two package lists. I did notice the versions are different, but it wasn't clear that we couldn't upgrade the packages in both runtimes. You are right that if we did this, then some packages will have breaking changes for existing node actions, so perhaps this is a reason not to consolidate further.

some initial notes coming -- very rough descriptions.  I will break this over several comments

# 1. Feed Architecture Choices

There are at least 3 strategies for creating a feed: "Hooks", "Polling" and "Connections".

## Hooks

"Hooks" means we set up a feed using a webhook facility from another service.   In this strategy, we configure a webhook on a service to POST directly to a whisk URL to fire a trigger.  This is by far the easiest and most attractive option for implementing low-frequency feeds.
- The github feed is implemented using webhooks.

## Polling

"Polling" means that we arrange a whisk action to poll an endpoint periodically to fetch new data.
This is easy to build, but is low performance, and is limited by the polling interval.
- I have a prototype of a MessageHub feed using polling.

## Connections

"Connections"  means that we stand up a separate service somewhere that maintains a persistent connection to a feed source.    The connection based implementation might interact with a service endpoint via long polling, or to set up a push notification.
- Our cloudant changes feed is connection based.   We are working on a high-performance MessageHub connection-based feed using Kafka consumers.

# 2. Difference between Feed and Trigger

Some definitions:
- Whisk processes **events** which flow into the system.
- A **trigger** is simply a name for a class of events.   Each event belongs to exactly one trigger.   A good analogy is "topic" in pub-sub world.    A Rule T -> A means "whenever an event from trigger T arrives, invoke action A with the trigger payload.
- A  **feed** is a stream of events which all belong to some trigger T.    A feed is controlled by a **feed action** which handles creating, deleting, pausing, and resuming the stream of events which comprise a feed.    The feed action typically interacts with external services which produce the events, via a REST API that manages notifications.

# 3.  Implementing Feed Actions

The feed action is a normal OpenWhisk action, but it should accept the following parameters:
- lifecycleEvent: one of 'CREATE', 'DELETE', 'PAUSE', or 'UNPAUSE'
- triggerName: the fully-qualified name of the trigger which contains events produced from this feed.
- authKey: the Basic auth credentials of the OpenWhisk user who owns the trigger just mentioned

The feed action can also accept any other parameters it needs to manage the feed.  For example the cloudant changes feed action expects to receive parameters including 'dbname', 'username', etc.

When the user creates a trigger with the --feed parameter, the system automatically invokes the feed action with the appropriate parameters.

For example,assume the user has created a `mycloudant` binding for `cloudant` with their username and password as bound parameters.  Then when the user issues:

`wsk trigger create T --feed mycloudant/changes -p dbName myTable`,

then under the covers the system will do something equivalent to:
`wsk action invoke mycloudant/changes -p lifecycleEvent CREATE -p triggerName T -p authKey <userAuthKey> -p password <password value from mycloudant binding> -p username <username value from mycloudant binding> -p dbName mytype`

The feed action takes these parameters, and is expected to take whatever action is necesssary to set up a stream of events from cloudant, with the appropriate configuration, directed to the trigger T.    For cloudant, the action happens to talk directly to a `cloudanttrigger` service we've implemented with a connection-based architecture.   We'll discuss the other architectures below.

A similar feed action protocol occurs for `wsk trigger delete`.    We have not yet implemented pause and unpause, but they will be similar.

i think it'll be very important to include a description of how event data is going to flow into whisk via triggers. as far as i see, we often need a long-running process between whisk and the event source, whereas this lrp receives the event data (as a result of the feed-based trigger creation), and then translates the data into `wsk trigger fire` calls.

(Moving to briefer text now to get the initial outline in before discussion starts)

# 4. Implementing Feeds with hooks.

Setting up a feed via a hook is **_by far_** the easiest way to start, and should be the recommended way to encourage users to create feeds (according to SJF.   System MessageHub devotees often argue differently --but SJF does not believe Kafka consumers can ever be as easy as webhooks, and SJF believes we should stress simple UX above all else).

With this method there is _no need_ to stand up any persistent service outside of whisk.  _All_ feed management happens naturally though stateless whisk actions.

When invoked with `CREATE` the feed action simply installs a webhook for some other service, asking the remote service to POST notifications to the appropriate `fireTrigger` URL in whisk.

The webhook should be directed to send notifications to a URL such as:
`POST /namespaces/{namespace}/triggers/{triggerName}`

# 5.  Implementing Feeds with polling.

It is possible to set up an action to poll a feed source entirely within whisk, _without the need to stand up any persistent connections or external service_.

For feeds where a webhook is not available, but do not need high-volume or really quick response times, polling is an attractive option and should be recommended.

To set up a polling-based feed, the feed action takes the following steps when called for `CREATE`:
1.   The feed action sets up a periodic trigger (T) with the desired frequency, using the `whisk.system/alarms` feed. (meta!)
2.   The feed developer creates a `pollMyService' action which simply polls the remote service and returns any new events.
3.  The feed action sets up a rule T -> pollMyService.

That's it.   We've implemented a polling-based trigger entirely using whisk actions, without any need for a separate service.

> With this method there is no need to stand up any persistent service outside of whisk.

i agree we should offer to have the ability to integrate as easy as possible with webhooks.

however, today that requires webhooks send their payload with an application/json msg type.

several webhooks also use other msg types, so need to document that constrain and open an issue to allow more msg types. also, we need to document the webhook based approach, as you did above (need to add auth information)

re the polling approach -- i think we'll have to work through in which context the action doing the polling is being executed. if it's done in the context of the user, he'll get charged for the resource consumption, which will come across as being weird, since the user shouldn't have to know that the impl of a feed is using actions and shouldn't have to pay for it.

# 6. Implementing Feeds via Connections

The previous 2 methods are easy .. but if you want a high-performance feed, there is no substitute for persistent connections and long-polling or similar techniques.

Since OpenWhisk actions are stateless, right now there is no way keep a persistent connection open to a third party.   So instead, we are forced to stand up a separate service (outside of whisk) that runs all the time.   We call these **provider services**.  A provider service can maintain connections to third party event sources that support long polling or other connection-based notifications.   

The provider service should provide a REST API that allows the whisk feed action to control the feed.   The provider service acts as a proxy between the event provider and whisk -- when it receives events from the third party, it sends them on to whisk by firing a trigger.

The cloudant built-in feed is the canonical example -- it stands up a cloudanttrigger service which mediates between cloudant notifications over a persistent connection, and whisk triggers.

The alarm feed is implemented with a similar pattern.

We will soon provide a MessageHub feed with a similar pattern.

For the moment, these provider services must POST events to whisk in order to fire triggers.  Eventually, we will hook up MessageHub events directly into whisk to avoid the POST overhead.   

The connection-based architecture is the highest performance option -- but it's far more difficult to operate and maintain than the polling and hook architectures.   The provider service must be production-quality: it must be highly-available and fault-tolerant.    Our current providers do not meet this requirement, and will need work to reach production quality standards.

.sh scripts are ready for installing this push package into openwhisk.  One decision to be made is how to integrate the tests from outside packages. See https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/562

appears to be so - thanks.

Well, one more remark from me:
there are already issues like https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/502 and https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/74, opened nearly one week ago, and there are folks assigned to fix them with pull requests. The only thing that the assignees do not know is that we are moving from ant to ansible. 
It is not good that folks are doing things conflicting with each other. Maybe there is a lack of communication, but I hope this is something we need to improve in future.

@paulcastro please review. This will pick up the latest tagged 0.2.x (which is currently 0.2.0). Andrew specifically needs 0.2.1, but it hasn't been tagged yet. That being said, as soon as the tag is in place, this code will pick up 0.2.1.

Why not just leave the source code for the tests in place `catalog/wsk-pkg-pushnotifications/tests/` and configure gradle to resolve dependencies and run the tests.
